abstract: To one attaché, the August attack on a British agency in Kabul is a reminder that while Afghanistan's future relies on many things, its culture may be its most inspirational asset.
snippet: To one attaché, the August attack on a British agency in Kabul is a reminder that while Afghanistan's future relies on many things, its culture may be its most inspirational asset.
lead_paragraph: Funnily enough, I was in New York when it happened. It was a short breather after several months in Kabul - a treat for my children, whom I hadn't seen for so long. We'd been out all day - MoMA, Harlem for lunch, Yankees tickets, a cruise past the Statue of Liberty. There was a reflection on the water of the development at ground zero as we steered by. "That's why you're in Kabul?" my kids asked.

headline.main: They Heard the Word Culture, and They Reached for Their Gun
